articles.title: UPCOMING EVENTS
articles.summary: The article details several upcoming astronomy events for September and October, including the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) monthly meetings featuring a slide and equipment night and a presentation on Java eclipse experiences. Other major events listed are the Twelfth Annual Tehachapi Star Party, the Tenth Annual AANC Astronomy Conference at UC Berkeley with speakers, an astrophotography display, and a swap meet, and an Indoor Star Party in Los Gatos for public observing.

articles.title: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP) Announcements
articles.summary: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP) announced two items: the availability of a free solar system table detailing planet and satellite characteristics, and a public lecture series on new developments in astronomy. The lecture series, featuring prominent speakers on diverse topics like cosmology and black holes, will be held at Stanford University's Dinkelspiel Auditorium on October 20th.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: The SJAA offers a telescope loan program to its members, providing three telescopes (6-inch, 12-inch Dobson, and 14-inch Dobson) for a two-month period. Members are instructed to arrange pickup with the current holder and notify the club once the telescope is borrowed. The 6-inch telescope requires cradle repair, and contact details for the current holders are provided.

articles.title: NEW MEMBER:
articles.summary: This brief article announces the birth of Alan Marling, son of club members Jack and Nancy Marling. The announcement extends congratulations to the family, lightheartedly suggesting Alan will soon become an astrophotographer.

articles.title: AANC REGISTRATION FORM
articles.summary: This document is a registration form for an AANC event, detailing fields for attendee information, affiliation, and address. It includes options for participants to give a talk or present a paper, alongside a breakdown of registration fees, banquet choices for September 17th at Spengers, and weekend box meal options with associated costs. Instructions for sending the completed form and payment to Cindy Miller, with checks payable to AANC, are provided, along with a note about receiving a confirmation letter.

articles.title: HENRY COE
articles.summary: This article recounts a star party held at Henry Coe Park on August 6, 1983, where the author enjoyed exceptionally clear skies despite arriving late. Participants observed the Milky Way, various deep-sky objects, and remarkably, the Andromeda galaxy with the naked eye, despite some sky glow from nearby Morgan Hill. The event featured several telescopes and engaged astronomers, making for a very enjoyable observing session.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STAR PARTY
articles.summary: On August 6, a star party at Fremont Peak gathered amateur astronomers, including SJAA members. Despite initial oppressive heat, numerous flies, and high clouds, the weather improved, allowing for earnest observing after sunset. Attendees included Frank Dibbell, Gary Rice, Jackie Rice, and Phyllis Rose, among others.

articles.title: Watts, and Rick Sarrica. Upon arriving Rick announced that he left the base to his 14" Dobsonian AT HOME. After much talk of illegal wood cutting (use the stump for a base), Rick created a new base from three spikes, a rachet handles, and a beach towel! There ought to be a prize for such ingenuity.
articles.summary: During an astronomy observing session, Rick Sarrica cleverly improvised a temporary base for his 14" Dobsonian telescope using spikes, rachet handles, and a beach towel after forgetting the original base at home. Despite this initial challenge, participants enjoyed a night of pleasant temperatures, good skies, and observed various celestial objects, including a Jupiter shadow transit and numerous deep-sky objects.

articles.title: How good is Frank Dibbell's C-11?
articles.summary: This brief article humorously extols the exceptional optical performance of Frank Dibbell's C-11 telescope. An anonymous viewer, seemingly astounded by the clarity and detail observed, exclaimed that they could "see the toenails on that Husky," highlighting the instrument's remarkable resolving power when viewing distant subjects.

articles.title: YOSEMITE STAR PARTY
articles.summary: Members from various astronomical societies attended the Yosemite Star Party at Glacier Point on August 5-6. Despite initial overcast conditions, participants later enjoyed exceptionally clear, dark skies, observing early Perseid meteors, a shadow transit on Jupiter, and the Salyut 7 space station. The event provided a memorable experience of high-altitude observing, highlighting the contrast with lower-contrast viewing areas.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article reports on the recent discoveries of three new comets: two by the Infrared Astronomical Satellite (IRAS) and one by amateur astronomer Kazimieras Cernis. It provides details on their magnitudes, orbital characteristics, and discovery circumstances, noting that Comet Cernis is currently visible in the morning sky. Additionally, it mentions Comet Kopff's visibility and briefly references a study of past amateur comet discoveries.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: The article details the discoveries of two comets: Comet Meier (1979l) and Comet Mori-Sato-Fujikawa (1975j). Rolf Meier found his comet in 1979 using a 16-inch reflector after extensive searching, noting its initial faintness. The second comet was a joint discovery by three Japanese observers in 1975, found at magnitude 10.8 in the morning sky.

articles.title: ADS
articles.summary: This document is a classifieds section listing various used astronomical equipment for sale, including several types of eyepieces, a Celestron C-5 telescope package, a C-90 telescope, a Sears refractor, and a 10-inch f/6.6 Newtonian telescope. It also outlines the policy for SJAA members to place free non-commercial advertisements in the EPHEMERIS publication.

articles.title: OPTRON SYSTEMS
articles.summary: OPTRON SYSTEMS is a company that supplies equipment for astronomers, advertising themselves with the slogan "Everything For Astronomers." They encourage potential customers to visit their showroom located at 704 Charcot Avenue, San Jose, CA 95131.

articles.title: Sept.
articles.summary: The provided document outlines a packed schedule of astronomy-related events for September, including multiple star parties at various locations like Fremont Peak, Henry Coe, and Tehachapi. It also details important club meetings such as a Board meeting and the SJAA General Meeting, which will feature a Slide and Equipment Night. Additionally, the month includes the AANC Annual Astronomy Conference and notes the dates for the New Moon and Full Moon.

articles.title: Oct.
articles.summary: The document outlines a series of astronomical events and club activities for October. It details several star parties, including public indoor and outdoor events at locations like Fremont Peak and Henry Coe State Park, as well as the Los Gatos Red Cross Building. Additionally, it lists a SJAA General Meeting featuring a presentation titled "Eclipse in Java" and a scheduled board meeting.

articles.title: General meetings:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to the University of Santa Clara's Alumni Science Hall, Room 102, for general meetings. It includes specific driving instructions from both northbound and southbound Hwy 17, as well as parking information and how to locate the room within the building. A map is also referenced to aid navigation to the meeting venue.

articles.title: Indoor Star Parties:
articles.summary: The document provides detailed driving directions to the "Indoor Star Parties" held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building. Attendees are instructed to take the Hwy 9 exit from Hwy 17 South, proceed on Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd., and then turn onto Rose Ave. to reach the parking lot.

articles.title: Henry Coe State Park:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) observing site within Henry Coe State Park, accessible via Hwy 101 South towards Gilroy. It includes specific landmarks, the gate location on a dirt road, and the club combination (4565) for access. Visitors are reminded to always lock the gate and use parking lights only after dark, with a recommendation to hike in first if arriving late.

articles.title: Fremont Peak State Park:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, starting from Hwy 101 south towards Salinas. It specifies the setup location for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) as the Coulter Camp overflow area and reminds visitors about the etiquette regarding parking lights after dark.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS continued....
articles.summary: The article discusses the discovery circumstances of two comets, highlighting why one remained undiscovered for weeks despite being observable due to its faintness and diffuseness. It then details the discovery of Periodic Comet Suzuki-Saigusa-Mori (1975k) by three Japanese astronomers on October 5, 1975, noting its brightness, position, rapid movement, and eventual close approach to Earth, along with its 466-year orbital period.

articles.title: Ephemeris for known Comets
articles.summary: This document provides ephemeris data for two periodic comets, Kopff (1982k) and Cernis (1983I), including their Right Ascension, Declination, and estimated magnitude for various dates. It also offers brief observational notes for each comet, such as visibility challenges or proximity to other celestial objects. The information aims to guide observers in locating these comets.

articles.title: Non-Profit Status
articles.summary: This article outlines an organization's plan to obtain non-profit, "charitable" status from the IRS to secure a permanent observing site. The club seeks to attract larger, tax-deductible donations, as current fundraising is insufficient for the project. This change is primarily for tax purposes and won't alter the club's educational and scientific activities, but requires legal assistance for the application process, for which the board is seeking attorney recommendations.

articles.title: AUGUST BOARD MEETING
articles.summary: The August Board Meeting focused on pursuing "charitable" status with the IRS, with a decision to hire a lawyer due to slow progress. Funds from auction profits were transferred to a long-term account for a permanent site, and the October board meeting was scheduled at the Red Cross to coincide with a star party, hoping for increased member participation. Discussions also included tabling a proposal to move elections and approving a memory board purchase, alongside a vote of thanks to Mrs. A. B. Gregory.

articles.title: New Business
articles.summary: This document outlines the agenda for a "New Business" section, detailing discussion points for an upcoming meeting. Topics include administrative updates such as financial reports, calendar planning, information on a future speaker, and a site survey.

articles.title: Old Business
articles.summary: This document outlines three key ongoing administrative items for a club: the status of club brochures, an update on their application for non-profit status with the IRS, and the current status of the club's computer. It appears to be an agenda or status report for internal club operations.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This article provides ephemerides for observing Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), recommending observations shortly after sunset, even in a light sky, due to potentially better 'seeing' conditions and reduced glare. It includes a schedule for GRS meridian transits in September and announces a suspension of predictions until next spring when Jupiter becomes more observable. The document also lists the officers and board members of the San Jose Astronomical Association.

articles.title: Space Shuttle Launch Delayed
articles.summary: The STS-8 Space Shuttle launch has been delayed by 10 days to August 30, due to additional checks required for the Tracking and Data Relay Satellite (TDRS). This delay consequently pushes the STS-9 Spacelab launch to October 28. The Challenger shuttle had been rolled out to the launchpad on August 2.

articles.title: TDRS Relays Data
articles.summary: On August 7, the Tracking and Data Relay Satellite (TDRS) successfully relayed S-band low-data-rate transmissions from the Landsat 4 spacecraft. TDRS later also relayed high-data-rate thematic mapper transmissions, marking the first time such data was received since Landsat 4's X-band transmitter failed several weeks prior.

articles.title: Landsat 4 Spacecraft Needs Repairs
articles.summary: The Landsat 4 satellite is experiencing three major failures, including a severe loss of electrical power due to faulty wiring, a failed thematic mapper link, and a non-functional prime command and data handling computer. A Space Shuttle repair mission is under consideration, which would necessitate lowering the satellite's orbit to a reachable altitude before control is lost. The backup D-prime spacecraft is scheduled for launch to mitigate the impact of these issues.

articles.title: Revised Shuttle Schedule
articles.summary: Mission STS-10 has been cancelled due to issues with the IUS upper stage. There is a possibility that missions STS-12 and STS-13 will be reversed, which would allow the Solar Maximum Satellite repair mission to proceed first. This change would provide an extra month to resolve the IUS problems before it is needed to launch TDRS-B.

articles.title: Window Damage
articles.summary: This article details two incidents of window damage on spacecraft. The Space Shuttle Challenger (STS-7) sustained a 0.0178-inch deep impact, likely from a micrometeorite or space debris, necessitating window replacement. Separately, a Salyut 7 space station window was struck on July 27, creating a 0.15-inch crater and a loud crack, though its structural integrity remained intact.

articles.title: More IRAS Discoveries
articles.summary: The Infrared Astronomical Satellite (IRAS) has made significant discoveries, including material circling the star Vega, which is now thought to be a very large asteroid belt instead of planets. Additionally, IRAS detected a previously unobserved 20 million-mile-long tail on comet Tempel 2, following its closest approach to the Sun in June.

articles.title: Delta Launches Schedules for September
articles.summary: The article outlines Delta's launch schedule for September, detailing two satellite missions. The RCA Satcom 2R launch is set for September 8th, followed by the Galaxy 2 communication satellite on September 22nd.

articles.title: Navstar Accuracy Increased for Civilians
articles.summary: The accuracy of Navstar (GPS) signals for civil users is set to increase to 100 meters when the system becomes operational in 1988. U.S. and allied military users will receive even higher accuracy. This development follows the recent issuance of a production contract for 28 Navstar GPS satellites.

articles.title: Soviets Marketing the Proton Booster
articles.summary: The Soviet Union has begun marketing its Proton booster for commercial satellite launches, quoting fees to Inmarsat for orbiting maritime communications satellites starting in 1988. This initiative places them in direct competition with Western launch providers such as Ariane and the Space Shuttle in the commercial space market.

articles.title: Ariane Bookings
articles.summary: The Ariane launch program has secured new orders, ensuring enough payloads to fill its flight schedule through at least its 24th mission. This update confirms the program's continued operational capacity for the foreseeable future.

articles.title: French Minishuttle
articles.summary: France is proposing the development of the Hermes minishuttle, designed to carry four crew members and a small cargo bay, launched by an Ariane 5 rocket. Separately, the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is taking membership renewals, with changes to their Sky & Telescope subscription policy. Members wishing to renew their SJAA membership or subscribe to Sky & Telescope should send their forms and remittance to the treasurer.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document is a membership application and renewal form for the SJAA organization. It prompts applicants to provide personal contact information and their areas of interest. The form outlines various membership tiers, including options with or without 'S&T' (likely Sky & Telescope magazine) and a junior membership, each with distinct annual fees.

articles.title: SMA EMERALDS
articles.summary: This document appears to be a header or mailing label for a publication titled 'SMA EMERALDS'. It provides a San Jose, CA address, identifies the content as 'TIME VALUE â€” DATED NEWS MATERIAL', and details bulk rate U.S. postage paid information for its distribution.
